title: Language Models are Few-Shot Graders
author: Chenyan Zhao (University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign), Mariana Silva (University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign), Seth Poulsen (Utah State University), ...
relevance_why: The paper explores automatic grading systems using Large Language Models (LLMs), which can be applied to enhance grading methodologies in audio and speech processing.
background: Automated Short Answer Grading (ASAG) systems leverage advanced machine learning techniques to evaluate open-ended student responses effectively.
contribution: The paper introduces an ASAG pipeline leveraging Large Language Models to solve the challenge of scalable and effective grading, achieving improved performance compared to existing models.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods in ASAG have struggled with accuracy and required extensive training data, often lacking the flexibility of generative feedback.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work implements few-shot learning and retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) strategies to select graded examples, significantly enhancing grading accuracy.

key_innovation: The integration of grading rubrics and contextual examples into LLM-based grading prompts improves both accuracy and interpretability of the feedback.
real_world_impact: The ASAG pipeline can reduce human grading workload in educational settings, potentially increasing the scalability of educational assessments.
limitations: The reliance on graded examples may require substantial storage and computational resources, which could limit its applicability in resource-constrained environments.

new_terms.few-shot learning: **Few-shot learning** is a machine learning approach where the model is trained to make predictions based on a limited number of training examples.
new_terms.retrieval-augmented generation: **Retrieval-augmented generation (RAG)** combines retrieval of relevant information from a database with generative models to improve response accuracy and contextual relevance.
